I understand that the JIRA exception handling is better for when the stored credentials for whatever reason "expire", but when the JIRA website is unreachable / goes down new error crop up.  An error dialog displays the following message:

An Internal error occurred during: "Get Changed Tasks"

Here is the stack trace:

org.tigris.jira.core.service.exceptions.ServiceUnavailableException: Unable to connect to server.  Please check the URL.
	at org.tigris.jira.internal.core.service.soap.SoapJiraService$StandardLoginToken.getCurrentValue(SoapJiraService.java:575)
	at org.tigris.jira.internal.core.service.soap.SoapJiraService.getServerInfo(SoapJiraService.java:159)
	at org.tigris.jira.core.service.CachedRpcJiraServer.initializeServerInfo(CachedRpcJiraServer.java:409)
	at org.tigris.jira.core.service.CachedRpcJiraServer.getServerInfo(CachedRpcJiraServer.java:458)
	at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.jira.core.JiraOfflineTaskHandler.getChangedSinceLastSync(JiraOfflineTaskHandler.java:303)
	at org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui.RepositorySynchronizationManager$GetChangedTasksJob.run(RepositorySynchronizationManager.java:191)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

It wouldn't be so bad, except that I get this error dialog during every synchronization interval.

I guess this precipitates - or rather, adds more emphasis to - the need to be able to put certain repositories into offline mode.
And may I say that stack trace looks absolutely disgusting with the forced line breaks in the mylar editor.
